Authors:
Sebastián Mena, Rafael E. Cárdenas, Krzysztof M Kozak,
María Fernanda Checa
Title:
Forest stratification shapes allometry and flight morphology
of tropical butterflies
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Keywords:
adaptive syndromes, ecomorphology, Ecuador, evolutionary
physiology, Lepidoptera, stratification
Abstract:
Studies of altitudinal and latitudinal gradients have
identified links between the evolution of flight morphology, landscape
structure and microclimate. Although lowland tropical rainforests offer
steeper shifts in conditions between the canopy and the understorey,
this gradient has received far less attention. Butterflies, because of
their great phenotypic plasticity, are excellent models to study
selection pressures that mould flight morphology. We examined data
collected over five years on 64 Nymphalidae butterflies in the
Ecuadorian Chocó rainforest. We used phylogenetic methods to control for
similarity resulting from common ancestry, to explore for relationships
between species stratification and flight morphology. We hypothesized
that species show morphological adaptations related to differing life
histories and metabolic rates, associated with canopy and understorey
micro-enviroments. Butterfly species living in each stratum presented
significantly different allometric slopes. Furthermore, a preference for
the canopy was significantly associated with low wing area to thoracic
volume ratios and high aspect ratios, but not with the relative distance
to the wing centroid, indicating extended use of fast flapping-flight
for the canopy butterflies and slow gliding for the understorey. Our
results suggest that microclimate differences in vertical gradients are
a key factor generating morphological diversity in flying insects.
